description:
'''Country music''', also known as '''country and [[Western music (North America)|western]]''' or simply '''country''', is a [[popular music|music genre]] known for its [[ballad]]s and dance tunes, identifiable by both traditional lyrics and harmonies accompanied by [[banjo]]s, [[mandolin]]s, [[fiddle]]s, [[harmonica]]s, and many types of [[guitar]]; either [[acoustic guitar|acoustic]], [[electric guitar|electric]], [[steel guitar|steel]], or [[resonator guitar|resonator]] guitars. Once called ''[[hillbilly music]],'' the term country music was popularized in the 1940s to give it a correct term. 

It originated in the [[Southern United States]], and spread throughout the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont area of United States]], from Louisiana along the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to New York. The music is believed to be derived from [[British folk music]], brought to the United States during early waves of immigration. Rooted in [[American folk music]], such as [[old-time music|old-time]] and Southern [[Appalachian music]], many traditions blended to form country music. In particular, this included [[cowboy]] and [[vaquero]] [[Western music (North America)|Western music]] and [[African-American music|African-American]] traditional folk songs and spirituals. [[Music of Mexico|Mexican]], [[Music of Ireland|Irish]], and [[Gospel music]] have had a formative influence on the genre, as have the [[music of Polynesia|Polynesian]] [[Music of Hawaii|Hawaiian music]] and the [[Southwestern United States|Southwestern]] styles of [[New Mexico music|New Mexico]] and [[Tejano music|Tejano]], as well as [[gospel music]], [[Jazz scale#Blues scale|blues modes]] from [[blues music]].

Country music has remained an integral part of the [[Music of the United States|American music scene]], with a recent revitalization in interest since the early 2020s. In 2023, 45% of Americans reported listening to country music, an uptick in the genre's popularity.
